articles.headline: Professors, Beware. In China, Student Spies Might Be Watching.
articles.snippet: In a throwback to the Mao era, China is deploying students as watchdogs against teachers. It’s part of a campaign by President Xi to eliminate dissent.
articles.abstract: In a throwback to the Mao era, China is deploying students as watchdogs against teachers. It’s part of a campaign by President Xi to eliminate dissent.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHENGDU, China — With a neon-red backpack and white Adidas shoes, he looks like any other undergraduate on the campus of Sichuan University in southwestern China.

articles.headline: In China, Working Mothers Say They Are Fired or Sidelined
articles.snippet: Women who become pregnant say that employers discriminate against them in defiance of labor laws, and go largely unpunished.
articles.abstract: Women who become pregnant say that employers discriminate against them in defiance of labor laws, and go largely unpunished.
articles.lead_paragraph: The women’s accusations briefly lit up the Chinese internet. Three employees of a big Chinese logistics company said their bosses had fired them or cut their pay after they became pregnant.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Elsie Chen

articles.headline: Job Market Shows Resilience, Quieting Recession Fears
articles.snippet: The economy added 128,000 jobs in October, a figure that would have been higher without the General Motors strike and other factors.
articles.abstract: The economy added 128,000 jobs in October, a figure that would have been higher without the General Motors strike and other factors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American jobs engine has been beaten and battered, but it just keeps chugging along.

articles.headline: Warren Leads Tight Iowa Race as Biden Fades, Poll Finds
articles.snippet: Ms. Warren garnered 22 percent in a New York Times/Siena College poll, to 19 percent for Bernie Sanders. Pete Buttigieg has surged, while Mr. Biden’s travails have put the race in flux.
articles.abstract: Ms. Warren garnered 22 percent in a New York Times/Siena College poll, to 19 percent for Bernie Sanders. Pete Buttigieg has surged, while Mr. Biden’s travails have put the race in flux.
articles.lead_paragraph: The top Democratic presidential candidates are locked in a close race in the 2020 Iowa caucuses, with Senator Elizabeth Warren slightly ahead of Senator Bernie Sanders, Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Ind., and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., according to a New York Times/Siena College poll of likely Democratic caucusgoers.

articles.headline: Inside the Debate Between Netflix and Big Theater Chains Over ‘The Irishman’
articles.snippet: Scorsese’s Netflix gangster epic will play in select theaters before it streams. “It’s a disgrace,” says John Fithian, the head of the theater owners organization.
articles.abstract: Scorsese’s Netflix gangster epic will play in select theaters before it streams. “It’s a disgrace,” says John Fithian, the head of the theater owners organization.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Netflix and the owners of the major theater chains could have made a lot of money together, if only they had seen eye to eye on the release of “The Irishman.” And people across the country could have seen the film, Martin Scorsese’s gangster epic, the way it was meant to be seen, on the big screen, in the dark, with tubs of popcorn on their laps.

articles.headline: Elizabeth Warren Proposes $20.5 Trillion Health Care Plan
articles.snippet: Ms. Warren would impose huge tax increases on businesses and billionaires to pay for “Medicare for all,” but she said she would not raise taxes on the middle class.
articles.abstract: Ms. Warren would impose huge tax increases on businesses and billionaires to pay for “Medicare for all,” but she said she would not raise taxes on the middle class.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Elizabeth Warren on Friday revealed her plan to pay for an expansive transformation of the nation’s health care system, proposing huge tax increases on businesses and wealthy Americans to help cover $20.5 trillion in new federal spending.
articles.byline: By Thomas Kaplan, Abby Goodnough and Margot Sanger-Katz

articles.headline: Google to Buy Fitbit for $2.1 Billion
articles.snippet: The deal represents an aggressive attempt by Google to bolster its lineup of hardware products.
articles.abstract: The deal represents an aggressive attempt by Google to bolster its lineup of hardware products.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Google said on Friday that it was buying Fitbit, the maker of fitness-tracking devices, in a $2.1 billion deal that closes the gap with Apple in the growing market for wearable electronics. But the deal raises concerns that the internet company is gaining private health information about its users.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Adam Satariano
